papers.authors: Akkentli, F.; Jang, I. k.; Choi, Y.; Yoo, D.; Oh, E. J.-H.; Na, C. H.; Ha, S.; Kang, S.-U.

papers.authors: Lehmann, S.; Schraen-Maschke, S.; Vidal, J.-S.; Delaby, C.; Blanc, F.; Paquet, C.; Allinquant, B.; Bombois, S.; Gabelle, A.; Hanon, O.

papers.authors: Bernardo, A. M.; Marcotte, M.; Wong, K.; Sharmin, D.; Prandey, K.; Cook, J. M.; Sibille, E.; Prevot, T. D.

papers.title: Brain DNA methylomic analysis of frontotemporal lobar degeneration reveals OTUD4 and CEBPZ in shared dysregulated signatures across pathological subtypes
papers.authors: Fodder, K.; Murthy, M.; Rizzu, P.; Toomey, C. E.; Hasan, R.; Humphrey, J.; Raj, T.; Lunnon, K.; Mill, J.; Heutink, P.; Lashley, T.; Bettencourt, C.

papers.title: Ketone body metabolism declines with age in mice in a sex-dependent manner
papers.authors: Eap, B.; Nomura, M.; Panda, O.; Garcia, T. Y.; King, C. D.; Rose, J. P.; Leone, T. C.; Kelly, D. P.; Schilling, B.; Newman, J. C.

papers.title: Ketone body metabolism declines with age in mice in a sex-dependent manner
papers.authors: Eap, B.; Nomura, M.; Panda, O.; Garcia, T. Y.; King, C. D.; Rose, J. P.; Leone, T. C.; Kelly, D. P.; Schilling, B.; Newman, J. C.

papers.title: A minimally-invasive method for serial cerebrospinal fluid collection and injection in rodents with high survival rates
papers.authors: Zou, Y.; Han, J. R.; Yang, Y.; Wu, T. W.; Shi, T.-T.; Li, W.

papers.title: Exome-wide analysis reveals role of LRP1 and additional novel loci in cognition
papers.authors: Chakraborty, S.; Kahali, B.

papers.title: Chronic intermittent propofol attenuates surgery-induced neuroinflammation, apoptosis, and cognitive impairment in aged mice
papers.authors: Nagarajan, R.; Lyu, J.; Kambali, M.; Wang, M.; Pearce, R. A.; Rudolph, U.

name: Alzheimer's Disease: Diagnosis
description: Diagnostics, biomarkers and their relationship to AD phenotypes.

papers.title: Genetic, clinical underpinnings of subtle early brain change along Alzheimer’s dimensions
papers.brief: It is shown that manifestations of brain changes in early asymptomatic stages can be detected via a novel deep semi-supervised representation learning method and deepen the understanding of the multifaceted pathogenesis of AD beyond the brain.
papers.authors: J. Wen; Zhijian Yang; I. Nasrallah; Yuhan Cui; G. Erus; D. Srinivasan; A. Abdulkadir; E. Mamourian; G. Hwang; Ashutosh Kumar Singh; M. Bergman; J. Bao; E. Varol; Zhen Zhou; Aleix Boquet-Pujadas; Jiong Chen; A. Toga; A. Saykin; T. Hohman; P. Thompson; S. Villeneuve; R. Gollub; A. Sotiras; K. Wittfeld; H. Grabe; D. Tosun; M. Bilgel; Y. An; D. Marcus; Pamela J. LaMontagne; S. Heckbert; T. Austin; L. Launer; Mark Espeland; C. Masters; P. Maruff; J. Fripp; S. Johnson; J. Morris; M. Albert; R. Bryan; S. Resnick; L. Ferrucci; Yong Fan; M. Habes; D. Wolk; Li Shen; H. Shou; C. Davatzikos

papers.title: Signs and symptoms associated with a need for supervision in patients with Alzheimer's disease
papers.brief: Clinicians and caregivers can aid clinicians and caregivers in prognosis and planning, suggest symptoms to target with non-pharmacological and pharmacological treatments to forestall this important functional milestone, and suggest priorities for future research.
papers.authors: C. C. Huey; A. Kociolek; K. Fernandez; M. Hernandez; R. Gottesman; M. Barker; S. Cosentino; Y. Stern

papers.title: A multimodal intervention for Alzheimer's disease results in multifaceted systemic effects reflected in blood and ameliorates functional and cognitive outcomes
papers.authors: J. Roach; L. Edens; D. R. Markewych; M. Rapozo; J. Hara; Gustavo Glusman; C. Funk; J. Bramen; P. Baloni; W. Shankle; L. Hood

papers.title: Amyloid and Tau Pathology are Associated with Cerebral Blood Flow in Nondemented Older Adults with and without Vascular Risk Factors for Alzheimer's Disease
papers.authors: C. G. Swinford; S. Risacher; A. Vosmeier; R. Deardorff; E. Chumin; M. Dzemidzic; Y.-C. Wu; S. Gao; B. McDonald; K. Yoder; F. Unverzagt; S. Wang; M. Farlow; J. Brosch; D. Clark; L. Apostolova; J. Sims; D. J. Wang; A. Saykin

papers.title: Naturally occurring Alzheimer’s disease in rhesus monkeys
papers.authors: Zhenhui Li; Xiaping He; Shihao Wu; Rongyao Huang; Hao Li; Zhengbo Wang; Limin Wang; Dongdong Qin; Yu Kong; Yingqi Guo; Xia Ma; C. Turck; Zhiqi Xiong; Wenchao Wang; Xintian Hu

papers.title: Optimal combinations of CSF biomarkers for predicting cognitive decline and clinical conversion in cognitively unimpaired participants and mild cognitive impairment patients: A multi-cohort study
papers.brief: P-tau/A{beta}42 is sufficient for predicting progression in AD, with very high accuracy, and adding NfL improves the prediction of all-cause dementia conversion and cognitive decline.
papers.authors: G. Salvadó; V. Larsson; K. Cody; N. Cullen; E. Jonaitis; E. Stomrud; G. Kollmorgen; N. Wild; S. Palmqvist; S. Janelidze; N. Mattsson-Carlgren; H. Zetterberg; K. Blennow; S. Johnson; R. Ossenkoppele; O. Hansson

papers.title: Association between Serum Biomarker Profile and Real-World Evidence of Disability in Multiple Sclerosis
papers.brief: Serumprotein biomarker profiles improve the prediction of real-world MS disability status beyond clinical profile alone or clinical profile plus individual protein biomarker, reaching clinically actionable performance.
papers.authors: W. Zhu; C. Chen; L. Zhang; T. Hoyt; E. Walker; S. Venkatesh; F. Zhang; F. Qureshi; J. Foley; Z. Xia

papers.title: Plasma phosphorylated tau 181 predicts amyloid status and conversion from mild cognitive impairment to dementia stage; major impact of renal function on diagnostic performance in the BALTAZAR cohort
papers.brief: Chronic kidney disease, creatinine and glomerular filtration rate were independently associated with plasma P-tau181 concentrations, thereby altering the optimal cutpoints for A{beta}+ or conversion to dementia detection, making this blood biomarker central to AD management.
papers.authors: S. Lehmann; S. Schraen-Maschke; J. Vidal; C. Delaby; F. Blanc; C. Paquet; B. Allinquant; S. Bombois; A. Gabelle; O. Hanon

papers.title: Associations between affective/vegetative neuropsychiatric symptoms and brain morphology in aging people with mild cognitive impairment and Alzheimer's disease.
papers.brief: Findings show the implication of fronto-temporal regions with sleep disorders, depression and appetite changes, and contribute to a better understanding of brain morphological differences between CN, MCI and AD with respect to all five NPS.
papers.authors: A. Cannizzaro; L. Ronat; L. M. El Haffaf; A. Hanganu

papers.title: Statistical Evaluation of the Test Threshold for the Alzheimer's Disease EEG Coherence Marker
papers.brief: If synaptic disconnection as the neuropathology of Alzheimer's disease (AD) is responsible for the brain's inability to integrate diverse regions into efficient networks, then electroencephalographic data may be utilized to identify Alzheimer's dementia.
papers.authors: C. Radinski; G. Perez

papers.title: What does heritability of Alzheimer’s disease represent?
papers.brief: Estimates of heritability in Alzheimer’s disease, the proportion of phenotypic variance explained by genetics, are very varied across different studies, therefore, the amount of ‘missing’ heritability not yet captured by current genome-wide association studies is debated.
papers.authors: E. Baker; G. Leonenko; K. Schmidt; M. Hill; A. Myers; M. Shoai; I. de Rojas; N. Tesi; H. Holstege; W. M. van der Flier; Y. Pijnenburg; A. Ruiz; J. Hardy; S. J. van der Lee; V. Escott-Price

papers.title: Exploration of cortical Î²-Amyloid load in Alzheimer's disease using quantitative susceptibility mapping at 9.4T
papers.brief: This explorative study points toward the development of more accessible clinical methods to non-invasively detect effects of A{beta} accumulation in AD patients by exploring cortical features that can be detected by ultra-high field QSM at different spatial resolutions.
papers.authors: E. Tuzzi; A. Loktyushin; A. Zeller; R. Pohmann; C. Laske; K. Scheffler; G. Hagberg

papers.title: Biological age and brain age in midlife: relationship to multimorbidity and mental health
papers.brief: This study investigates whether elevated biological age and accelerated brain age are associated with an increased risk of multimorbidity using a large dataset from the Midlife in the United States (MIDUS) Refresher study and presents the first effort to test whether sex moderates the relationship between these surrogate aging biomarkers and multimOrbidity.
papers.authors: Fengqing Zhang; Hansoo Chang; S. Schaefer; J. Gou

papers.title: Hierarchical Two-Stage Cost-Sensitive Clinical Decision Support System for Screening Prodromal Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias
papers.brief: The primary stage is brief and effective at screening, with the optional two- stage technique further increasing specificity, and the hierarchical two-stage technique exhibited similar accuracy but with reduced costs compared to the more common single-stage paradigm.
papers.authors: M. Kleiman; T. Ariko; J. Galvin

papers.title: Age-specific activation of microglial genes in a mouse model of AD
papers.authors: Haoyang Zhou; Yizhou Yu

papers.title: Gut inflammation associated with age and Alzheimer's disease pathology
papers.brief: Calprotectin levels are higher with age, and that higher calprotectin was associated with greater amyloid burden among participants with an amyloids-confirmed AD dementia diagnosis, suggesting that intestinal inflammation may play a role in pathology development and that it may exacerbate the progression toward AD.
papers.authors: M. Heston; K. Hanslik; K. Zarbock; S. Harding; N. Davenport-Sis; R. Kerby; N. Chin; Y. Sun; A. Hoeft; Y. Deming; N. Vogt; T. Betthauser; S. Johnson; S. Asthana; G. Kollmorgen; I. Suridjan; N. Wild; H. Zetterberg; K. Blennow; F. Rey; B. Bendlin; T. Ulland

papers.title: Association between cancer and dementia risk in the UK Biobank: evidence of diagnostic bias
papers.brief: Investigation of the UK Biobank to generate and compare estimates for the cancer-dementia association using different analytical specifications designed to address different sources of bias found incident cancer diagnoses were associated with a higher risk of subsequent dementia diagnoses.
papers.authors: J. Wang; P. Buto; S. Ackley; L. Kobayashi; R. E. Graff; S. Zimmerman; S. Asiimwe; C. Calmasini; M. Glymour

papers.title: Menopause, Brain Anatomy, Cognition and Alzheimer’s Disease
papers.brief: It is confirmed that both early and surgical menopause are associated with a higher risk of developing AD, indicating that early and abrupt ovarian hormone deprivation might contribute to the development of the disorder.
papers.authors: M. Costantino; Grace Pigeau; Olivier Parent; Justine Ziolkowski; Gabriel A. Devenyi; N. Gervais; M. Mallar Chakravarty

papers.title: Virtual histology of Alzheimer’s Disease: why are amyloid-β plaques visible with X-ray phase-contrast imaging?
papers.brief: The fibrillar and elemental compositions of Aβ plaques in brain samples from different types of AD patients and different AD animal models were probed to establish a relationship between XPCT contrast and Aβ plaque characteristics and the hypothesis that the Aβ–related contrast in XPCT could be caused by the A β fibrils and/or by metal entrapment within the Aα plaques was tested.
papers.authors: Matthieu Chourrout; C. Sandt; T. Weitkamp; T. Dučić; D. Meyronet; T. Baron; J. Klohs; Nicolas Rama; H. Boutin; Shifali Singh; C. Olivier; M. Wiart; E. Brun; S. Bohic; F. Chauveau

papers.title: Synthesizing Images of Tau Pathology from Cross-modal Neuroimaging using Deep Learning
papers.brief: A convolutional neural network model is presented that can impute tau PET images with high accuracy and suggests that extending neuroimaging’s use with artificial intelligence to predict protein specific pathologies has great potential to inform emerging care models.
papers.authors: Jeyeon Lee; B. Burkett; Hoon-Ki Min; M. Senjem; Ellen Dicks; Nick Corriveau-Lecavalier; Carly T. Mester; H. Wiste; E. Lundt; M. Murray; A. Nguyen; R. Reichard; H. Botha; J. Graff‐Radford; L. Barnard; J. Gunter; C. Schwarz; K. Kantarci; D. Knopman; B. Boeve; V. Lowe; R. Petersen; C. Jack; David T. Jones

papers.title: Cerebrospinal fluid neurofilament light improves accurate distinction between neurodegenerative and psychiatric disorders at a cognitive neuropsychiatry service
papers.brief: Cerebrospinal fluid neurofilament light improved diagnostic accuracy, with potential to have led to earlier, accurate diagnosis in a real-world setting using a pre-specified cut-off, adding weight to translation of NfL into clinical practice.
papers.authors: M. Kang; D. Eratne; H. Dobson; C. Malpas; M. Keem; C. Lewis; J. Grewal; V. Tsoukra; C. Dang; R. Mocellin; T. Kalincik; A. Santillo; H. Zetterberg; K. Blennow; C. Stehmann; S. Varghese; Q.-X. Li; C. Masters; S. Collins; S. Berkovic; A. Evans; W. Kelso; S. Farrand; S. Loi; M. Walterfang; D. Velakoulis

papers.title: Biological aging of human body and brain systems
papers.brief: It is found that an organ's biological age selectively influences the aging of other organ systems, revealing a multiorgan aging network and revealing the multisystem nature of human aging.
papers.authors: Y. Tian; V. Cropley; A. Maier; N. Lautenschlager; M. Breakspear; A. Zalesky

papers.title: Feasibility of linking markers of dementia-related health in primary care medical records to cognitive function assessed in a specialist dementia service
papers.brief: This feasibility study highlights the challenges in obtaining consent and linking primary and secondary care EHR in dementia, and in extracting cognitive function scores from dementia service EHR.
papers.authors: M. Marshall; P. Campbell; J. Bailey; C. Chew‐Graham; P. Croft; M. Frisher; R. Hayward; R. Negi; T. Rathod-Mistry; S. Singh; L. Robinson; A. Sumathipala; N. Thein; K. Walters; S. Weich; K. Jordan

papers.title: A spatiotemporal map of the aging mouse brain reveals white matter tracts as vulnerable foci
papers.brief: It is revealed that glia aging is profoundly accelerated in white matter compared to cortical areas, and distinct clusters of brain regions that differentially express genes associated with 3 human neurodegenerative diseases are discovered, highlighting regional aging as a potential modulator of disease.
papers.authors: Oliver Hahn; Aulden G. Foltz; Micaiah Atkins; Blen Kedir; Patricia Moran-Losada; Ian H. Guldner; Christy Munson; Fabian Kern; Róbert Pálovics; Nannan Lu; Achint Kaur; Jacob Hull; J. Huguenard; Andreas Keller; B. Lehallier; T. Wyss-Coray

name: Alzheimer's Disease: Neuroinflammation
description: Relationships between neuroinflammation and amyloid and tau pathologies and its effect on disease trajectory.

papers.title: Age-specific activation of microglial genes in a mouse model of AD
papers.authors: Haoyang Zhou; Yizhou Yu

papers.title: Targeting neuroinflammatory pathways using Nanoligomers™ is neuroprotective in prion disease
papers.brief: Critically, the Nanoligomer™ protected the brain from prion-induced spongiotic change, neuronal loss, and significantly increased life span, indicating that Nanolgomer™ inhibition of inflammatory pathways can prevent neuronal death and slow the progression of neurodegenerative diseases.
papers.authors: Sydney J. Risen; Sean Boland; Sadhana Sharma; Grace Weismann; Payton Shirley; Amelia D. Hines; Arielle J. D. Hay; Vincenzo S Gilberto; S. McGrath; A. Chatterjee; P. Nagpal; J. Moreno

papers.title: Border-associated macrophages mediate the neuroinflammatory response in an alpha-synuclein model of Parkinson disease
papers.brief: A combinatorial approach of single-cell RNA sequencing and depletion experiments found that BAMs played an essential role in immune cell recruitment, infiltration, and antigen presentation and were identified in post-mortem PD brain in close proximity to T cells.
papers.authors: Amanda Schonhoff; David A. Figge; GP Williams; AJ Jurkuvenaite; N. Gallups; GM Childers; JM Webster; D. Standaert; JE Goldman; A. Harms

papers.title: Brain and systemic inflammation in de novo Parkinson's disease
papers.brief: 18F-DPA-714 imaging demonstrated increased central inflammation in de novo PD subjects compared to controls, and longitudinal follow-up will be important to determine whether the presence of inflammation predicts cognitive decline.
papers.authors: T. Yacoubian; Yaxiu Fang; A. Gerstenecker; A. Amara; N. Stover; L. Ruffrage; C. Collete; R. Kennedy; Y. Zhang; H. Hong; H. Qin; J. McConathy; E. Benveniste; D. Standaert

papers.title: Novel Master Regulators of Microglial Phagocytosis and Repurposed FDA-approved Drug for Treatment of Alzheimer Disease
papers.brief: Repurposed riluzole, an FDA-approved ALS drug that upregulates SLC1A2 activity, and discovered that it stimulated phagocytosis of Aβ1-42 in human primary microglia and decreased hippocampal amyloid plaque burden/phosphorylated tau levels in the brain of aged 3xTg-AD mice emphasize the utlility of the integrative approach for repurposing drugs for AD therapy.
papers.authors: Kuixi Zhu; Qianying He; S. Tsai; Dinusha Maheepala Mudalige; M. Henrion; Syed Zaidi; Lau Branden; A. Tang; Mika P. Cadiz; Rachel Hodos-Nkhereanye; Sara Moein; Melissa Alamprese; David A. Bennett; P. D. De Jager; J. Frye; N. Ertekin-Taner; Y. Kuo; P. Ronaldson; Rui Chang

papers.title: Neurodegenerative disease associated pathways in brain of the triple transgenic Alzheimer’s model are reversed in vivo following two weeks peripheral administration of fasudil
papers.brief: The results bolster the repurposing potential of fasudil by demonstrating an anti-neurodegenerative phenotype in a disease context and highlight the potential of in vivo transcriptional profiling of drug activity.
papers.authors: R. Killick; C. Elliott; E. Ribe; M. Broadstock; C. Ballard; D. Aarsland; Gareth Williams

papers.title: Gradual cerebral hypoperfusion in a knock-in mouse model of Alzheimer’s disease triggers cortical network dysfunctions
papers.authors: Surjeet Singh; Sean G. Lacoursiere; J. Mehla; Mojtaba Nazari; R. Sutherland; R. J. McDonald; M. Mohajerani

papers.title: Neuronal pentraxin Nptx2 regulates complement activity in the brain
papers.brief: It is identified that the secreted neuronal pentraxin Nptx2 binds complement C1q and thereby regulates its activity in the brain and that diminished NPTx2 levels might exacerbate complement-mediated neurodegeneration in FTD patients.
papers.authors: Jiechao Zhou; S. D. Wade; David Graykowski; Mei-Fang Xiao; Binhui Zhao; L. Giannini; J. E. Hanson; J. V. van Swieten; Morgan Sheng; P. Worley; B. Dejanovic

papers.title: Naturally occurring Alzheimer’s disease in rhesus monkeys
papers.authors: Zhenhui Li; Xiaping He; Shihao Wu; Rongyao Huang; Hao Li; Zhengbo Wang; Limin Wang; Dongdong Qin; Yu Kong; Yingqi Guo; Xia Ma; C. Turck; Zhiqi Xiong; Wenchao Wang; Xintian Hu

papers.title: PKB/AKT attenuates Lewy Body-like pathology in primary neurons via Cathepsins B and D
papers.brief: LVs are utilized to express constitutively active myristoylated serine-threonine protein kinase AKT1 (mAKT1) in primary dopamine neurons to demonstrate the critical importance of lysosomal enzymes for processing misfolded α-syn and establish a basis for the use of LVs to develop neuroprotective gene therapy strategies for dopamine neurons in PD.
papers.authors: J. Konovalova; Ş. Er; J. Barut; K. Rafa-Zabłocka; K. Luk; M. Figiel; M. Airavaara; A. Domanskyi; P. Chmielarz

papers.title: Loss of estrogen unleashing neuro-inflammation increases the risk of Alzheimer’s disease in women
papers.brief: Pooling together the multiple pieces of evidence, it is concluded that the loss of estrogen unleashing neuro-inflammation increases the women’s risk of Alzheimer's disease.
papers.authors: Fuhai Li; I. Oh; Sayantan Kumar; A. Eteleeb; Aditi Gupta; W. Buchser; C. Xiong; Sessions F. Cole; E. McDade; Celeste M. Karch; O. Harari; Philip R. Payne; C. Cruchaga

papers.title: Gut inflammation associated with age and Alzheimer's disease pathology
papers.brief: Calprotectin levels are higher with age, and that higher calprotectin was associated with greater amyloid burden among participants with an amyloids-confirmed AD dementia diagnosis, suggesting that intestinal inflammation may play a role in pathology development and that it may exacerbate the progression toward AD.
papers.authors: M. Heston; K. Hanslik; K. Zarbock; S. Harding; N. Davenport-Sis; R. Kerby; N. Chin; Y. Sun; A. Hoeft; Y. Deming; N. Vogt; T. Betthauser; S. Johnson; S. Asthana; G. Kollmorgen; I. Suridjan; N. Wild; H. Zetterberg; K. Blennow; F. Rey; B. Bendlin; T. Ulland

papers.title: Distinct effects of disease-associated TREM2 R47H/+ and T66M mutations on iPSC-derived microglia
papers.brief: While the TREM2 T66M mutation impairs microglial movement and uptake processes, the T REM2 R47H/+ mutation additionally confers multiple potentially detrimental effects on human microglia, likely to underlie its association with AD.
papers.authors: Jay Penney; W. T. Ralvenius; Anjanet Loon; Oyku Cerit; V. Dileep; Blerta Milo; Hannah Woolf; L. Tsai

papers.title: Impact of cellular prion protein expression on disease progression and pathology in two mouse models of Alzheimer’s disease
papers.brief: A longitudinal study in two commonly used AD mouse models is performed and it is proposed that these two mouse models produce Aβ oligomers with different conformations, and binding to PrPC and the subsequent activation of toxic signalling cascade will occur only when the A β oligomer species with appropriate conformation are present.
papers.authors: Silvia A. Purro; Michael Farmer; Elizabeth Noble; Claire J. Sarell; Megan O. Powell; D. Yip; Lauren Giggins; L. Zakka; David X. Thomas; M. Farrow; Andrew J. Nicoll; D. Walsh; J. Collinge

papers.title: A multiplex platform to identify mechanisms and modulators of proteotoxicity in neurodegeneration
papers.brief: Domain mapping and a deep mutational scan of DNAJB6 support the critical importance for DNAJB 6 phase separation in its effects on multiple RNA-binding proteins, and suggest that this property can be further tuned to generate novel variants with enhanced activity that might illuminate potential avenues for clinical translation.
papers.authors: Samuel J. Resnick; S. Qamar; J. Sheng; Lei Haley Huang; Jonathon Nixon-Abell; Schuyler Melore; C.W. Chung; Xuecong Li; Jingshu Wang; Nancy R. Zhang; N. Shneider; C. Kaminski; F. Ruggeri; G. Schierle; Peter H. St George-Hyslop; A. Chavez

papers.title: Neuroprotective tissue adaptation induced by IL-12 attenuates CNS inflammation
papers.brief: An IL-12-induced neuroprotective adaption of the neuroectoderm critically involved in maintaining CNS tissue integrity during inflammation is uncovered, indicating parallel mechanisms in humans.
papers.authors: M. Andreadou; F. Ingelfinger; D. De Feo; Ekaterina Friebel; S. Tuzlak; Teresa M.L. Cramer; B. Schreiner; P. Eede; S. Schneeberger; Maria Geesdorf; Frederike Ridder; Christina A. Welsh; D. Kirschenbaum; Shiva K. Tyagarajan; M. Greter; F. Heppner; S. Mundt; B. Becher

papers.title: Somatostatin slows Aβ plaque deposition in aged APPNL-F/NL-F mice by blocking Aβ aggregation in a neprilysin-independent manner
papers.authors: Declan Williams; Bei Qi Yan; Hansen Wang; Logine Negm; Christopher Sackmann; Claire E Verkuyl; Vanessa Rezai-Stevens; Shehab Eid; C. Sato; J. Watts; H. Wille; G. Schmitt-Ulms

papers.title: Formation of amyloid loops in brain tissues is controlled by the flexibility of protofibril chains
papers.brief: It is concluded that ex vivo protofibril chains possess greater flexibility than that imparted by hydrogen-bonded networks characteristic of mature amyloid fibrils, such that they are able to form end-to-end connections.
papers.authors: Alyssa M. Miller; Sarah Meehan; C. Dobson; M. Welland; D. Klenerman; M. Vendruscolo; F. Ruggeri; T. Knowles

papers.title: Meningeal IL-17 producing T cells mediate cognitive impairment in salt-sensitive hypertension
papers.brief: The data unveil a critical role of meningeal T-cells and macrophage IL-17 signaling in the neurovascular and cognitive dysfunction of hypertension and suggest novel therapies to counteract the devastating effects of hypertension on cognitive health.
papers.authors: M. Santisteban; G. Faraco; David Brea Lopez; G. Wang; Melissa Sobanko; Rose K. Sciortino; Gianfranco Racchumi; A. Waisman; J. Anrather; C. Iadecola

papers.title: A spatiotemporal map of the aging mouse brain reveals white matter tracts as vulnerable foci
papers.brief: It is revealed that glia aging is profoundly accelerated in white matter compared to cortical areas, and distinct clusters of brain regions that differentially express genes associated with 3 human neurodegenerative diseases are discovered, highlighting regional aging as a potential modulator of disease.
papers.authors: Oliver Hahn; Aulden G. Foltz; Micaiah Atkins; Blen Kedir; Patricia Moran-Losada; Ian H. Guldner; Christy Munson; Fabian Kern; Róbert Pálovics; Nannan Lu; Achint Kaur; Jacob Hull; J. Huguenard; Andreas Keller; B. Lehallier; T. Wyss-Coray

papers.title: Death induced by survival gene elimination (DISE) contributes to neurotoxicity in Alzheimer’s disease
papers.brief: The data provide first evidence of a contribution of DISE to the neurotoxicity seen in AD suggesting that increasing the levels of protective miRNAs in the brain or blocking the activity of toxic R-sRNAs could lead to a novel way of treating the disease.
papers.authors: Bidur Paudel; Si-Yeon Jeong; Carolina Pena Martinez; Alexis D. Rickman; Ashley Haluck-Kangas; E. Bartom; Kristina Fredriksen; Amira Affaneh; J. Kessler; J. Mazzulli; A. E. Murmann; E. Rogalski; C. Geula; Adriana B Ferreira; Bradlee L. Heckmann; D. Green; K. Sadleir; R. Vassar; M. Peter

papers.title: „APP family member dimeric complexes are formed predominantly in synaptic compartments“
papers.brief: It is shown that dimerized APP originates mostly from neurons and is enriched in synaptosomes, suggesting that loss of dimers of full-length APP might correlate with loss of synapses in the process of AD.
papers.authors: S. Schilling; A. August; M. Meleux; C. Conradt; L. Tremmel; S. Teigler; V. Adam; E. Koo; S. Kins; S. Eggert

papers.title: On a mechanistic impact of transmembrane tetramerization in pathological activation of RTKs
papers.brief: The observed structural and dynamic effects of the V536E mutations in the context of PDGFRA TM tetramer provide an interesting possibility that an effect of oncogenic TM mutations can go beyond alternating structure and dynamics of TM dimeric states and also promote formation of higher-order oligomers that may directly contribute into the ligand independent signaling ofPDGFRA and other RTKs.
papers.authors: A. Polyansky; R. Efremov

papers.title: Natural and pathological aging distinctively impact the vomeronasal detection system and social behavior
papers.brief: It is indicated that aging distinctively disrupts the processing of social olfactory cues decreasing social odor exploration, discrimination and habituation in both wild type senescent (2-year-old) mice and in 1- year-old double mutant model of Alzheimer’s disease (APP/PS1Het).
papers.authors: Adrián Portalés; P. Chamero; Sandra Jurado

papers.title: Inflammation of the retinal pigment epithelium drives early-onset photoreceptor degeneration in Mertk-associated retinitis pigmentosa
papers.brief: It is found that loss of Mertk and reduced expression/loss of Tyro3 led to RPE inflammation even before eye-opening, and inflammation drives severe, early-onset PR degeneration-associated with MERTk loss of function.
papers.authors: M. Mercau; Yemsratch T. Akalu; Francesca Mazzoni; Gavin Gyimesi; E. Alberto; Y. Kong; B. Hafler; S. Finnemann; C. Rothlin; Sourav Ghosh
